entry.title: Template for Haidian district unified exam papers (old version)
entry.content:
As a “Haidianer”, you have passed at least 24 district-wide unified examinations from grade 7 to 12 (two per semester, i.e. the mid-term and the final exams). Have you ever noticed the layout design of your exam papers?

You may have noticed that the layout design is standardized and orderly throughout papers of all subjects, similar to that of NCEE papers, in large contrast to the poorly typed papers of monthly tests held by your own school. (Actually, there are many differences between the layout design of Haidian exam papers and that of the NCEE papers, which I’ll elucidate in detail in later articles. From my perspective, though being a small detail, each district should pay attention to the layout design of their unified exam papers, trying to imitate the real NCEE papers because, after all, the unified exams are targeted at NCEE, and the more simulated in each detail, the better students are prepared for the real battle, at least psychologically.)

I don’t remember when this layout was first used, perhaps it can date back to the 2000s, but I’m sure that its life (partly) ceased in the spring of 2016. Since then, the layout design of Haidian unified exam papers has changed at least three times, and it has been no longer typeset by BookMaker since the third change. (From my observation, it may have been typeset by InDesign since then.)

In commemoration of this classic layout, I reproduced a template of it recently. Here I’ll display the first 2 pages. The content is retrieved from the Chinese subject of the first mock test for the High School Entrance Examination, 2013. (source: Beijing Haidian Teachers Training College)

Fonts used:

  • Fangzheng Shusong (SS)
  • Fangzheng Heiti (H)
  • Fangzheng Kaiti (KT)
  • Fangzheng Xiaobiaosong (XBS)
  • Baizheng NPS (BZ)
  • Heizheng NPS (HZ)

If you need a sample PDF file, please contact m@narita.me.

entry.title: “v” or “nu”? A typesetting detail one should pay attention to
entry.content:
Take a look at the image below. What are the highlighted letters in each equation respectively?

It’s easy to recognize the letter in Eq.① is $v$ (the Latin alphabet v) representing velocity and that in Eq.② is $\nu$ (the Greek alphabet nu) representing frequency, since both equations are classic in physics. In certain contexts, the recognition is easy. However, if we take away the contexts, could it be possible for one to know whether a glyph is v or nu? Or, if these glyphs appear in a shared context? Confusion may arise.

This confusion is caused by the fonts “Times New Roman” (TNR) and “Symbol”. Both equations are typed in MathType with TNR for Latin alphabets and Symbol for Greek ones. As you can notice, the v and nu look quite similar.

Let’s see how other fonts deal with these two alphabetsA:

It’s obvious that all fonts in the table other than TNR and Symbol design the glyphs of the two in a clearer way to avoid confusion. In these fonts, v is smoother, while nu is sharper with a point at the bottom, thus the distinction being significant. To correctly display these two alphabets in your document, a normal and universal method should be adopted. As far as I have seen, some document creators even use “upsilon” (υ) to replace v so as to distinguish v from nu, which is totally wrong.

Here I offer two suggestions on appropriate ways to address this issue.

  • First and most recommended, use a DTP tool more suitable for typesetting scientific content, such as TeX and Founder BookMaker, rather than MS Word.
  • Second, if the template you use requires you to use TNR as the main font, try to use another font for “v” in math environments. To my knowledge, Palatino Linotype or Book Antiqua are widely used in nationwide unified exams (e.g. NCEE) and high school physics textbooks[1]. See the image below for the comparison after the font alternation.

So next time, when typesetting a scientific document that includes v and nu simultaneously, consider the aforementioned advice, for more standardized typesetting that complies with scientific publishing normalities, and not confusing your peer reviewers if you submit a paper, or your students if you make an exam paper.

Note

  1. Computer Modern is the default font of TeX. Founder BZ NPS & S10 are default fonts of Founder BookMaker.

Who am I?

I’m Hermit Narita, M. Eng. candidate, B. Eng. in Air Transport.

Academically, I currently conduct research on the application of operations research (OR) and intelligent optimization algorithms in the aviation industry and have published several papers in SCI and Ei journals. I also engage in works related to visual design, publishing, and media industries. Culturally, I belong to Sinosphere (漢字文化圈), and I’m keen on studying CJKV unified ideographs and their corresponding languages. In daily life, I’m an aircraft and cityscape photographer, diecast aircraft model collector, writer, calligrapher, cyclist, and radio amateur.

My research interest and the major contents of my blog include but are not limited to:

  • Civil aviation
